metadata.synopsis: Default Dialogue - the conversation you can have with Minthara at any thime when she's a member of your party. You can ask her about herself, or events that you've experienced together during your adventures. Her responses to you may differ based on some of the choices you make after she joins. Provided you don't betray her for another, she will continue to stand by you, revelling in the violence that follows.

15.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
15.text: You do not shy from the parasite's powers.

55.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
55.text: Karlach is desperate for somebody to fill the hole where her heart used to be.

148.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
148.text: But you made it clear that you are mine, and mine alone.

298.speaker: Player
298.text: Exactly. I don't want anyone else.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: Yes. And that you are mine.

27.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
27.text: Let the others desire you - let them desire us both. They cannot have us so long as we belong to one another.

163.speaker: Player
163.text: I have my doubts about you, but let's see where it goes.

429.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
429.text: Dismiss your doubts. If I cannot be sure of your devotion to me, I would prefer not to share my body or mind with you at all.

245.speaker: Player
245.text: You've been colder than normal. Is everything ok between us?

221.speaker: Player
221.text: You gave the name alurlssrin to the bond we share. What does it mean?

471.speaker: Player
471.text: That's not a word I ever expected to hear from you.

254.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
254.text: It is not a word I ever expected to say.

334.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
334.text: I have had many lovers, but none ever earned my trust and affection as you have.

318.speaker: Player
318.text: Then I agree. I alurlssrin you too.

390.speaker: Player
390.text: A pity. I don't feel the same way.

220.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
220.text: Then cast the word from your thoughts and never think of it again. It should be easy enough given how much escapes that mind of yours.

474.speaker: Player
474.text: What do you make of the situation at the Guildhall?

366.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
366.text: The Guild's hold on the city's criminal enterprises is slipping.

306.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
306.text: They are vulnerable because they have not had enough competition in recent times.

222.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
222.text: In Menzoberranzan, my House has been the most significant power for thousands of years, but it has never been a peaceful reign. That is by design.

71.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
71.text: We do not eradicate our enemies entirely because they make us strong. And if there is no external threat, we turn our knives on one another.

488.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
488.text: It is only through competition that any of us can remain strong. The Guild may have become too comfortable to remember that.

351.speaker: Player
351.text: How do you think we should resolve the situation at the Steel Watch Foundry?

92.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
92.text: A frontal assault against such formidable foes would be ill-advised.

135.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
135.text: If you fight an army, kill the general and the troops will disperse. If you fight a giant, lacerate its tendons and spine to bring it down to size.

491.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
491.text: We cannot hope to dismantle every Watcher, so we should avoid their attention until we can strike their nerve centre.

374.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
374.text: It is rare that gnomes prove useful, but the runepowder bomb the Ironhands provided should be our weapon of choice.

428.speaker: Player
428.text: What about the Gondian workforce? They need our help.

385.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
385.text: That is only relevant if we also need their help.

99.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
99.text: Controlling an unruly slave by holding a knife to the throat of their child is a time-honoured tactic - the collars and hostages work on the same principle.

269.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
269.text: These people are nothing to us. Why should we care if the knife does its work?

282.speaker: Player
282.text: What if there is no way to shut them all down?

152.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
152.text: Do not be fooled by their appearance. The Watchers are forged and cast like machines, but they are a hivemind like any other.

246.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
246.text: A central intelligence guides them. If we find the source of that intelligence, we can destroy it.

226.speaker: Player
226.text: Orin is dead. You have your vengeance.

219.speaker: Player
219.text: The Emperor has offered us a special tadpole. We'll become partial mind flayers, but we'll get great powers in turn...

460.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
460.text: We will need every advantage to survive the battles that are to come, and my illithid parasite has already shown its worth.

270.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
270.text: If this superior tadpole is capable of unlocking my mind's full potential, it is a tempting proposition.

438.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
438.text: Its influence on you is plain to see - you are sublime.

93.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
93.text: I am surprised you have not drawn on its power yourself.

192.speaker: Player
192.text: Perhaps I'll share it with you later. But not yet.

485.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
485.text: As you should. When I am stronger, we are stronger.

317.speaker: Player
317.text: You're on edge. Orin's influence, I assume?

194.speaker: Player
194.text: You seem nervous. What's bothering you?

294.speaker: Player
294.text: I'm curious about your thoughts regarding Raphael's deal.

261.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
261.text: I do not want a devil to hold my fate in his hands any more than a god.
261.context: NodeContext: taling about a proposed deal from the devil Raphael, pragmatically against it

314.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
314.text: Aren't you tired of bowing and begging for scraps of power from your patron?
314.context: NodeContext: spoken to a warlock character - genuine curiosity that they are so obedient to their patron

113.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
113.text: Aren't you tired of bowing and praying before authority figures?
113.context: NodeContext: spoken to a cleric player - genuine curiosity that they're so obedient to their god

299.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
299.text: Dealing with Raphael was foolish, but understandable. Giving him the Crown would be a grave error though.
299.context: NodeContext: cautioning the player for making a bad choice, the deal with Raphael

31.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
31.text: If anyone should have that power, it should be us.
31.context: NodeContext: determination, referring to the power of the Crown of Karsus

238.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
238.text: I say we put the devil from our minds, and trust in ourselves. If anyone should have the power of the Crown, it should be us.
238.context: NodeContext: determined - the'Crown' is her ultimate goal, an artefact that will give her power to control the world

413.speaker: Player
413.text: Have you ever seen anything like the Steel Watch before?

127.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
127.text: No. They seem to combine the obedience and strength of a golem with the precision and intelligence of their creator.
127.context: NodeContext: impressed - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

188.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
188.text: For now, they act as a defensive wall of steel, but their true purpose is conquest. Mechanised slaughter.
188.context: NodeContext: analytical, impressed - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

139.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
139.text: Imagine how quickly the grove would have fallen if we had machines like those to command. Imagine how quickly a city would fall.
139.context: NodeContext: becoming excited about this notion - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

145.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
145.context: NodeContext: impressed - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

140.speaker: Player
140.text: I wish we had such devices of our own.

371.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
371.text: The tools used to construct and control them may well be here in the city. If we were to control Baldur's Gate, the Steel Watch could be ours.
371.context: NodeContext: analytical - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

167.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
167.text: Better to control the elder brain though. Iron crumbles, steel breaks, but the power of a thought or an idea can be infinite.
167.context: NodeContext: first line, she's switching track from the Steel Watch to a better target, the Elder Brain. Then explaining her thinking. talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

206.speaker: Player
206.text: In the right hands, they could keep the peace without risk of bloodshed.

353.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
353.text: Without bloodshed on the winning side, perhaps. The machines will always need something to kill, if only to show their strength.
353.context: NodeContext: dismissing the idea that the machines can be peacemakers, acting without 'bloodshed' - talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

170.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
170.text: That is why we should make sure we are the ones giving the orders, rather than the ones on the receiving end of them.

436.speaker: Player
436.text: We need to destroy them, and put a stop to this 'revolution'.

381.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
381.text: We could melt every Steel Watcher down to dross and change nothing. We cannot stop an idea, and we cannot stop progress.
381.context: NodeContext: The 'idea' is something like the Manhattan Project to her mind. talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

234.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
234.text: And nor should we. Instead, it falls to us to make sure we control the idea and profit from progress.
234.context: NodeContext: The 'idea' is something like the Manhattan Project to her mind. talking about the Steel Watch, powerful machines that patrol the streets of Baldur's Gate

288.speaker: Player
288.text: You know there is a darkness within me - I have learned its origin.

393.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
393.text: Tell me, ust-nor. Or show me. My mind is open to you.
393.context: NodeContext: ust-nor - my love. Drow phrase.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Connect your mind with her's and show her every grotesque thought and deed in full, gory detail.

39.speaker: Narrator
39.text: *Exposed to the limitless horror of your dreadful imagination, Minthara's mind buckles, snaps... and then burns hot.*

187.speaker: Narrator
187.text: *She absorbs every detail, whether memory or dream, and drinks deep of them. You sense a desire in her equal in strength to your darkest urge.*

112.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
112.text: Elgg-hor... duk-tak... slayer. There are many names for you, my love, and all of them inspire dread. You are exquisite.
112.context: NodeContext: ELG-hor DOOK-tak (slayer, killer) spoken with reverence - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

274.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
274.context: NodeContext: acknowledging her own excellence - proud

69.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
69.text: We must find the Temple of Bhaal, slaughter Orin, and claim your inheritance.
69.context: NodeContext: determination - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

218.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
218.text: Then I will rule by your side, my slayer.
218.context: NodeContext: awe and love - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

174.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
174.text: Ecstatically so. It makes my heart race.
174.context: NodeContext: speaking of being afraid, but in a thrilling way- just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

513.speaker: Player
513.text: I'm not sure I can control these powers.

115.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
115.context: NodeContext: strict - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

357.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
357.text: Yours is a heritage of murder. It cannot be ignored or evaded. You will either kill or be killed.
357.context: NodeContext: strict, persuasive - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

404.speaker: Player
404.text: I want nothing to do with Bhaal.

252.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
252.text: You cannot deny your own blood.
252.context: NodeContext: strict - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

450.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
450.text: Elgg-hor... duk-tak... slayer. There are many names for you, and all of them inspire dread. You are exquisite.
450.context: NodeContext: ELG-hor DOOK-tak (slayer, killer) spoken with reverence - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

327.speaker: Player
327.text: I am a Bhaalspawn, and I intend to claim my heritage.

470.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
470.text: A child of Bhaal? What horrors your mind must hold.
470.context: NodeContext: quiet awe - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

225.speaker: Narrator
225.text: *She joins with your thoughts excitedly, unprepared for what she will find there.*

453.speaker: Player
453.text: I am a child of Bhaal, but I believe I can resist my father's savagery.

181.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
181.text: You are heir to a divine inheritance that few would be able to command... but I believe you could.
181.context: NodeContext: quiet awe and persuasiveness - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

153.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
153.text: To reject it would be to reject godhood. You would lose the possibility of shaping the world to fit your desires.
153.context: NodeContext: quiet awe and persuasiveness - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

472.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
472.context: NodeContext: warning that her romance with the player would end if they rejected a power inside themselves

12.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
12.text: Bhaal is not like the Absolute. He will not control you... he will unleash you.
12.context: NodeContext: persuasive - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

519.speaker: Player
519.text: This is my choice to make, not yours.

441.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
441.text: Tell me. Or show me. My mind is open to you.
441.context: NodeContext: exited, anticipation - just discovered the person she's speaking to is a descendant of Bhaal, lord of murder

514.speaker: Player
514.text: Shadowheart may yet turn from Shar. Do you think she should?

52.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
52.text: I would rather we were all free of the gods, but Shadowheart's connection to Shar may provide her access to the city's Sharran cloister.

440.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
440.text: If they serve her, they serve us, and we need every possible ally.

527.speaker: Player
527.text: Why do you favour an alliance with Gortash?

443.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
443.text: He is the only authority figure in Baldur's Gate worth a damn.
443.context: NodeContext: speaking of the benefits of an alliance with Gortash, a villain and dictator

493.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
493.text: Even as the elder brain tears at the foundations of the city, he stands strong, and looks for solutions.
493.context: NodeContext: speaking of the benefits of an alliance with Gortash, a villain and dictator

207.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
207.text: Better for us to be a solution rather than a problem for his Steel Watch to scrape off the street.
207.context: NodeContext: speaking of the benefits of an alliance with Gortash, a villain and dictator

501.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
501.text: I am glad you recognised the benefits of that approach. If he proves troublesome, we can always kill him later, when his guard is down.
501.context: NodeContext: speaking of the benefits of an alliance with Gortash, a villain and dictator

117.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
117.text: It would be wise to return to him and pledge an oath of allegiance before he declares us enemies of the peace.
117.context: NodeContext: speaking of the benefits of an alliance with Gortash, a villain and dictator

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?

70.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
70.text: Yes. I only know it through history books and hearsay - a city of murder and grief.
70.context: NodeContext: talking about Baldur's Gate - curious

5.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
5.text: It is already living up to the legend.
5.context: NodeContext: with a smile, talking about Baldur's Gate's reputation as a city of murder

284.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
284.text: I expect it will live up to its legend.
284.context: NodeContext: with a smile, talking about Baldur's Gate's reputation as a city of murder

347.speaker: Player
347.text: I'm curious about Menzoberranzan. Tell me about your home.

373.speaker: Player
373.text: Do you know anything about Gortash?

473.speaker: Player
473.text: You've encountered Orin before. What can you tell me about her?

191.speaker: Player
191.text: Do you remember all that you did in the Absolute's name?

321.speaker: Player
321.text: You must be glad Ketheric is dead.

462.speaker: Player
462.text: When did you first encounter the cult of the Absolute?

147.speaker: Player
147.text: I tried to hold to the tenets of my oath, but I faltered again.

43.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
43.text: You did not falter, you freed yourself. Your oath is a burden - let it go.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: My oath is broken, just as you said it should be.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Lost. I don't know who I am without my oath to guide me.

405.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
405.text: Good. I sensed you had the courage to find your own strength - I am glad you have proven me right.

30.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
30.text: We stand against gods and abominations, and so far we have proved their equals.

364.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
364.text: Unshackled from whatever redundant principles held you back, we can transcend them.

142.speaker: Player
142.text: Conflicted. I don't know if this is for the best.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: My oath as a paladin is broken.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: You're a fellow paladin - what's the nature of your oath?

48.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
48.text: I took up my oath  long ago, when I swore bloody vengeance against any who defied Lolth. Now, I myself have sinned against the Spider Queen.
48.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

250.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
250.text: Though my faith is shattered, my oath endures. I am sworn to destroy all those who serve the Absolute.
250.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

258.speaker: Player
258.text: That seems hypocritical, considering you intend to take the power of the Absolute for yourself.

342.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
342.text: When I have had my vengeance on the cult, I do not know if my oath will still hold.
342.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

94.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
94.text: I do know that when I take the Absolute's power, I will not lose control of it as our enemies have. I will harness it to create a more perfect world.
94.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

335.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
335.text: Any who object to the laws of that world will have no place in it, of course, and I will gladly eradicate them.
335.context: NodeContext: matter-of-fact - looking forward to a grim future

247.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
247.text: What of your oath, paladin? Are you true to it?

176.speaker: Player
176.text: It is the source of my strength. I will never break it.

241.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
241.text: There are other sources of strength. Trust in your allies - trust in me.
241.context: NodeContext: insistent - trying to persuade a paladin to break their oath

383.speaker: Player
383.text: Sometimes I think it holds me back from my true potential.

233.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
233.context: NodeContext: insistent - trying to persuade a paladin to break their oath

87.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
87.text: We are threatened by murderous gods, and otherworldly entities that despise our very existence.
87.context: NodeContext: persuasive - trying to persuade a paladin to break their oath

490.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
490.text: When you made your oath, you could not have predicted this dark path we now follow, or the things that would be asked of you.
490.context: NodeContext: persuasive - trying to persuade a paladin to break their oath

54.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
54.text: You cannot allow yourself to be held back by an ideal.
54.context: NodeContext: persuasive - trying to persuade a paladin to break their oath

177.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
177.text: It is not noble, it is necessary. If we do not destroy the cultists, they will destroy everything.

444.speaker: Player
444.text: Your crusade against the Absolute is nothing more than a convenient excuse for bloodshed.

310.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
310.text: Do you think me a fool? If it were blood I wanted, I would choose easier victims rather than challenging gods and cosmic aberrations.
310.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

376.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
376.text: Abandon your preconceptions of who I am and why I act, and know this - my fight against the cult is righteous.
376.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin. It's meaningful to her, but she is unsure if it still gives her what she needs to survive

416.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
416.text: We are all that stands between this world and annihilation.

319.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
319.text: My oath is broken. I still hold to the tenets of vengeance, but I am no longer bound by any word of vow.
319.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin, now broken. She feels liberated.

524.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
524.text: I am more interested in power than penitence.
524.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin, now broken. She feels liberated.

138.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
138.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin, now broken. She feels liberated.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: Hardly surprising. You only serve yourself.

80.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
80.text: Not true. While our bond holds, and we have a common enemy, I serve your cause too.

457.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
457.text: Free of my oath, I am more capable than ever of achieving our goals.
457.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin, now broken. She feels liberated.

401.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
401.text: Once I have had my vengeance and the Absolute is ours to control, people will pledge an oath to our cause. Conquest, and dominion.
401.context: NodeContext: reflecting on her oath as a paladin, now broken. She feels liberated.

235.speaker: Player
235.text: You're a paladin - what's the nature of your oath?

506.speaker: Player
506.text: I felt a little strange after our last kiss.

308.speaker: Player
308.text: I'm curious to hear your thoughts about our companions.

449.speaker: Player
449.text: I need to talk to you about a private matter.

329.speaker: Player
329.text: I need to talk to you about a private matter.

208.speaker: Player
208.text: I need to talk to you about a private matter.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: You have gaps in your memory - so do I. Do you think the tadpole is the cause?

110.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
110.text: Not directly. My memories were not removed, they were obscured by the Absolute's voice - by its presence.

396.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
396.text: The tadpole is a conduit for that voice, not its origin, and while the Prism protects us, the Absolute cannot reach us.

516.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
516.text: As for the tadpoles themselves, for the moment I do not believe they are malevolent. They are incubating within our brain-matter, not feeding on it.

166.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
166.text: If they were, we would all spend our days in a berserk rage, and our nights talking to hamsters.
166.context: NodeContext: joking that if the tadpoles had eaten the party's brains they'd all behave like Minsc 'in a berserk rage etc'

122.speaker: Player
122.text: I yearn to kill. I only feel like myself when I'm killing.

131.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
131.text: Is there a reason you chose me as your confidante in this matter?

271.speaker: Player
271.text: I thought you'd understand - you're a killer too.

96.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
96.text: I take pleasure in harming my enemies, but I do not kill for the joy of it. Only when it serves my ambitions to do so.

10.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
10.text: As you should. But I am not sure that I can trust you.

20.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
20.text: There are those within Menzoberranzan that we call qu'lith quarthen - those driven-by-blood.

386.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
386.text: They are the mad, lost to all reason, and subservient to nobody. Even Lolth, malicious and brutal as she is, cannot abide them.

29.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
29.text: They kill, and cannot say why. So they are destroyed, for the greater good.

510.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
510.text: When you speak to me of yearning and urges to kill, I fear you are like them - controlled by a bloodlust that you do not comprehend.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: You misunderstand. I enjoy killing, but I can control myself.

67.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
67.text: Killing is necessary. It is good that you can take pleasure in it.

236.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
236.text: Just be sure that your urges do not lead you astray - we have enemies enough for you to sate your lusts on.

168.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
168.text: We do not need to make more because you indulge your every murderous whim.

368.speaker: Player
368.text: If that were the case, what would you do?

262.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
262.text: I would kill you without hesitation.

330.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
330.text: If it ever takes you, I will be there to put you down.

375.speaker: Player
375.text: I fear it may be true.

433.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
433.text: If it is, then your own death may be the only cure.

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: But for you to even speak of this to me shows that if there is a madness in you, it does not own you yet.

14.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
14.text: If it ever does, I will kill you without hesitation.

345.speaker: Player
345.text: I need help. I thought you might have experience with violent urges.

162.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
162.text: I do not have violent urges, I have violent intentions.

76.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
76.text: If somebody angers me, I hurt them not because I lose control of my temper, but because it teaches them not to anger me again.

259.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
259.text: If somebody causes me sorrow, I remove their ability to do so again. If that involves removing their head, so be it.

46.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
46.text: But I do not lash out or strike without reason.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: You have gaps in your memory - so do I. Do you think the tadpole is the cause?

281.speaker: Player
281.text: |I yearn to kill. I feel driven to sacrifice the one called Isobel.|

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Wait here in camp for now.

409.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
409.text: A mistake. I am your most valuable asset.

332.speaker: Player
332.text: On second thought, you should stay with me.

309.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
309.text: Of course. I belong in battle.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: Don't question me. Stay here in camp.

47.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
47.text: When you realise your mistake, I will be ready to join you again.

227.speaker: Player
227.text: Don't question me. Return to camp.

287.speaker: Player
287.text: Go to camp and wait for me there.

201.speaker: Player
201.text: I'd like you to join me.

118.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
118.text: Cast off one of the lessers who trail behind you, and I will gladly stand at your side.

56.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
56.text: Good. I do not like to stand idle.

88.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
88.text: I do not understand why the matrons - sorry, patriars - of the city do not open their gates to the refugees.

98.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
98.text: You look well. Are you ready to pursue our enemies?

101.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
101.text: I thought you might be in flames the next time I saw you. Karlach's touch has that effect on people.
101.context: InternalNodeContext: Player did act 1 romance scene with Gale, but not act 2 yet. Player did act 2 romanec scene with another character.

175.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
175.text: You should hurry back and warm your hands on her heart. Mine is altogether colder.

439.speaker: Player
439.text: I want to be with Karlach, I'm sorry if that hurts you.

74.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
74.text: If you intend to be with her, do not fool yourself into thinking it is more than a brief dalliance before her fire is extinguished for good.

467.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
467.text: She will die, you will grieve, and then you will be alone.

465.speaker: Player
465.text: I like the ice and the fire. Can't I have you both?

45.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
45.text: Karlach will take pleasure wherever she can find it. Her life is too short to do otherwise.

202.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
202.text: I can afford to have stricter expectations. I do not share anything that I desire.

461.speaker: Player
461.text: I am sorry I chose Lae'zel over you.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: I am sorry I chose Gale over you.

492.speaker: Player
492.text: I am sorry I chose Wyll over you.

228.speaker: Player
228.text: I am sorry I chose Karlach over you.

171.speaker: Player
171.text: I am sorry I chose Astarion over you.

387.speaker: Player
387.text: I am sorry I chose Shadowheart over you.

459.speaker: Player
459.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Astarion.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Karlach.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Lae'zel.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Wyll.

331.speaker: Player
331.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Gale.

389.speaker: Player
389.text: I guess you heard what happened between me and Shadowheart.

121.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
121.text: In times of crisis, it is not wise to horde resources - everything must be put to immediate use.

141.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
141.text: Has Wyll proposed marriage yet, or are you just one more frontier for his blade to tame?
141.context: InternalNodeContext: Player did act 1 romance scene with Gale, but not act 2 yet. Player did act 2 romanec scene with another character.

507.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
507.text: Whatever the case, I suggest you slip back into his arms and out of my sight.

352.speaker: Player
352.text: I want to be with Wyll, I'm sorry.

530.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
530.text: Perhaps he will sheathe his blade, and dedicate himself to your happiness one day.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: I was hoping I could share my time with both you and Wyll.

377.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
377.text: For all his rugged charm, Wyll is a man of tradition. He would not share you with a Duke's daughter, let alone an exile from the Underdark.

28.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
28.text: And besides, I do not share what I desire.

125.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
125.text: I cannot imagine it was an easy thing to reject Lae'zel's advances.

223.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
223.text: You are bold to seek me out after sharing your affections with another.
223.context: InternalNodeContext: DID ACT 2 romance with Gale then dumped him in another characters' inparty

32.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
32.text: Are those bite-marks on your neck, or did you contract some unpleasant rash from the vampire?
32.context: InternalNodeContext: PLAYER has only done act 1 Astarion scene - that means they just slept with him

354.speaker: Player
354.text: It was a mistake - you're the one I want.

214.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
214.text: Of course I am. But you no longer have me, and you never will.
214.context: NodeContext: arrogant - turning down someone who tells her they want her, after that person has cheated on her

25.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
25.text: As long as you do not let your lusts distract you from the fight, we do not need to speak of this again.

414.speaker: Player
414.text: Sorry. I didn't mean to hurt you.

434.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
434.text: Hurt me? You aren't capable. But you have disappointed me.

275.speaker: Player
275.text: I've made my choice - I'm with them now.

73.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
73.text: I can understand why you would choose a Duke's son over an exiled daughter of Menzoberranzan.

363.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
363.text: You were incapable of raising yourself to my standards - perhaps you will have better fortune lowering yourself to Karlach's.

97.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
97.text: What little I know of githyanki courtship suggests Lae'zel will not wish to share you. And nor do I.

124.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
124.text: Shadowheart likes to keep secrets, but the two of you could not keep this from me.

143.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
143.text: I advise you to walk away while you still can.

240.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
240.text: It is always thrilling to know that something you own is desired by another.
240.context: InternalNodeContext: DID ACT 2 romance with Gale, and dumped another character in their inparty

422.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
422.text: Astarion is so used to playing the nocturnal hunter, he thought you would make for easy prey.

242.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
242.text: I am surprised to see you standing. I thought Astarion might have sucked you dry by now.
242.context: InternalNodeContext: Player did act 1 romance scene with Gale, but not act 2 yet. Player did act 2 romanec scene with another character.

517.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
517.text: If he does bite too hard, do not come whimpering to me. He can drain you for all I care.

398.speaker: Player
398.text: I want to be with Astarion, I'm sorry.

394.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
394.text: You do not need to apologise. You will be scarcely capable of satisfying my appetites - the vampire may be more easily nourished.

380.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
380.text: All I ask is that you do not let your roving lusts distract from our goals.

410.speaker: Player
410.text: I was hoping I could share my time between you and Astarion.

186.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
186.text: I suspect that would puncture his fragile ego far more savagely than his fangs puncture your neck.

8.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
8.text: Astarion likes to put on a show of nonchalant decadence, but he is as delicate as a flake of snow.

178.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
178.text: Besides, that arrangement would not suit me either. I am not delicate, but I do not share what I desire.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: I'm sorry, for what it's worth.

272.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
272.text: You will be much sorrier if you continue to talk. Go. There is nothing more to say.

456.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
456.text: We enjoyed one another for a while. Sometimes that is enough.  Now go, there is nothing more to say.

72.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
72.text: A little, but it will fade.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: I don't want to end our relationship.

59.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
59.text: Then you should not have begun another.

336.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
336.text: In Menzoberranzan, I had a thousand suitors. Some were only attracted by my status, many only wanted my body - a rare few wanted all of me.

486.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
486.text: The more they pursued me, the less I desired them. I tired of them all.

34.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
34.text: Here, with you, I enjoyed that there was no pursuit, and there was no status. We simply were.

243.speaker: Player
243.text: I liked that too - we can have it again.

511.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
511.text: Then you must tell the wizard you belong to me. I am sure he will survive - after all, he has been rejected by a goddess in the past.
511.context: NodeContext: instructing player to break up with another character to stay with her - teasing

512.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
512.text: You have your charms, but you are far from divine.
512.context: NodeContext: with a smile - she's teasing

40.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
40.text: Then you must wound poor Karlach's heart. As if it were not broken enough already.
40.context: NodeContext: instructing player to break up with another character to stay with her - teasing

81.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
81.text: Good. Do not stray again - you belong to me, and I to you.

11.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
11.text: Then you must tell Lae'zel of your decision. If she is displeased, I will gladly teach her not to touch my property again.
11.context: NodeContext: instructing player to break up with another character to stay with her - teasing

38.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
38.text: Then you must give up any hopes of marrying into the Ravengard family. Tell Wyll of your decision.
38.context: NodeContext: instructing player to break up with another character to stay with her - teasing

489.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
489.text: Then you must tell Shadowheart of your decision. Do not worry - the sorrow of loss may be a fulfilling religious experience for her.
489.context: NodeContext: mocking Shadowheart (who is not present) while asking the player to break up with her.

372.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
372.text: Then you must tell Astarion you are no longer on the menu.
372.context: NodeContext: instructing player to break up with another character to stay with her - teasing

151.speaker: Player
151.text: I don't think I can go through with it.

502.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
502.text: Then go. There is nothing more to say.
502.context: NodeContext: abrupt, plain - player just broke up with her, and she's dismissing them. A little sad, but mostly quiet anger.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: You're right, it's for the best we aren't involved.

213.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
213.text: You have nothing more to say? Fine.

280.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
280.text: Either your face is decorated with fresh bruises, or you are blushing like a lovesick youth.
280.context: InternalNodeContext: Pre-partnered with companion, partnered with Gale.

325.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
325.text: Whatever the case, it seems Lae'zel has left her mark on you, and claimed you as her own.

320.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
320.text: I will leave you to enjoy her attentions. I hope you are strong enough to survive them.

18.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
18.text: I will leave you to enjoy her attentions. I hope you are strong enough to survive them.

412.speaker: Player
412.text: I am glad to be hers.

184.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
184.text: Then I am glad that you are no longer mine. You do not have the strength to satisfy both of us.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: I was hoping to share my time with you and Lae'zel.

311.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
311.text: Amusing. I am not sure you have the strength to satisfy either of us, let alone both.

104.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
104.text: The wizard hoped to weave a spell around you, and make you his.

337.speaker: Narrator
337.text: *As you approach Minthara, you feel her mind reaching out to yours, tentative and curious. Then it retreats, soft as a whisper.*

361.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
361.text: Baldur's Mouth is truly remarkable. I had thought the purpose of a broadsheet was to inform the people, but I see now that I was mistaken.

256.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
256.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

463.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
463.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

340.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
340.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

379.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
379.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

382.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
382.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

89.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
89.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

65.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
65.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

255.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
255.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

479.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
479.text: I need to think on what happened.
479.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

193.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
193.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

483.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
483.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

494.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
494.text: Not now. I need a moment.
494.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

316.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
316.context: NodeContext: Medium intensity - this is a 'backfill node' we want so we can use it to patch holes we might find in our dialogues at a later date if needed. Therefore, the context is very broad.

395.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
395.text: I do not have time for idle chatter.

407.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
407.text: Hard to believe she is dead after all that she did to me.

415.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
415.text: So - Shadowheart has attracted your attention. Are you not worried that the little amnesiac will forget you by morning?
415.context: InternalNodeContext: Pre-partnered with companion, partnered with Gale.

324.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
324.text: If you do slip from her mind, do not come scurrying back to my bed.

35.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
35.text: I will be with my weapons. Come find me, if you need me for the fight.

487.speaker: Player
487.text: I think I have a future with Shadowheart.

24.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
24.text: I am sure you do. It is a fine thing to build a future with somebody who does not know their past.

300.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
300.text: If you are careful and cunning in your manipulations, you can make them into almost anything you wish.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: I was hoping to share my time with you and Shadowheart.

164.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
164.text: I think Shadowheart will require all of your attention. I suspect she is rather needy once you break past that cold exterior.

431.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
431.text: If you are inclined to rekindle whatever affection there was between us, spare yourself the shame.

521.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
521.text: Young Wyll planned to court you, and to win your heart.

423.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
423.text: Shadowheart hoped to share her heart with you - what little of it she understands well enough to share.

525.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
525.text: Tell me - when you kissed the wizard, could you still taste Mystra on his tongue?
525.context: InternalNodeContext: Player did act 1 romance scene with Gale, but not act 2 yet. Player did act 2 romanec scene with another character.

23.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
23.text: Go unpick the weave with him. I will be with my weapons.

458.speaker: Player
458.text: Gale's a good man. I think we have a future together.

477.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
477.text: It might be a very short future. If you show him any of the tricks I taught you, he is liable to explode.

399.speaker: Player
399.text: I was hoping I could spend my time with both you and Gale.

57.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
57.text: I think his ardour would fizzle as quickly as his spells often do if he saw us together.
